title: Karwa chauth: Which side won the culture war?
text:
Yes, karwa chauth, there is polarisation here too! For convenience’s sake let’s calls one side, pativratas. And the other, feminazis. There is no high-level thinking to this choice of labels, I am simply following herd logic.

I learnt about pativratas from the same place where I have learnt most of Indian culture: Bollywood. Mock me if you like, but not before denying that life itself does not feel known till its tit bits are seen on the screen and thereby elevated into knowledge. When the story, the scene, the emotions of one map onto the other isn’t it eureka!?

Anyway, so for a two minute cinematic summary of the festival you could do worse than begin with the karwa chauth song in Kabhi Khushi Kabhi Gham. Right away you know this is a group gig, like solo pativrata no, no. Next, super bling is super obligatory. Everyone goes for the Christmas tree look. There is also the moon and sieve thing putting a very pretty filter effect on the pati. Then, and unfortunately this particular song skips this critical part, the pativrata finally breaks her fast – she has gone the whole day without even drinking water!

Now, the feminazis, as karwa chauth warriors call their opponents, are peeps who think it’s a bit much that only the wife fasts for the long life of husband, some reciprocity would be nice – and incidentally fair.

So which side is winning? In the bazaar yesterday the mehndi and choori waalas were out in strength. The metro women’s compartment was thinly occupied this morning. Neighbourhood kids say they have a school holiday today. Case closed.
